title: Dillington House Walking Route

images.title: Derek Harper / Dillington Park Lodge
images.caption: Dillington Park Lodge, Whitelackton, Somerset. Thatched 17th- and 18th-century house beside the former main road.

images.title: Derek Harper / Fishing lake, Dillington
images.caption: Fishing lake, Dillington, near to Whitelackington, Somerset. The small building at the water's edge is a pump house. Behind is the Eaglewood Park development, in which "derelict cattle pens and a silage pit have been transformed into quality, ecologically-sound offices". This is all on the east side of Dillington Park.

images.title: Derek Harper / West Lodge, Dillington Park
images.caption: West Lodge, Dillington Park. This pretty early C19 octagonal cottage ornee is at Ashwell, where the western drive to Dillington House leaves the B3168 at a bend.

images.title: Derek Harper / Sculpture at Dillington House
images.caption: Sculpture. The wooden figure (unable to trace any details so far) is beside footpath CH14/14 as it passes Dillington House in the background, and is one of several pieces of artwork in the grounds, doubtless related to the many art-related courses run at the centre.

images.title: Derek Harper / Dillington Park Farm
images.caption: Dillington Park Farm. The farm lies in the landscape park of the house. A workshop among the buildings houses a firm of cabinet makers

images.title: Derek Harper / The Pheasantry
images.caption: The Pheasantry. One of the outbuildings at the house. (Those holes look more suitable for doves than pheasants, although this building may date from between the C17 extinction of the bird and its reintroduction in the C19.)

images.title: Derek Harper / Dillington Park
images.caption: A view from the long drive that approaches the house from Whitelackington

images.title: Derek Harper / Cattle grid, Dillington House
images.caption: The drive through the east side of Dillington Park is followed by National Cycle Route 33, and a public footpath to Whitelackington. The cattle grid marks the edge of the formal gardens surrounding the house.

description: This walk visits the 16th century Dillington House near Ilminster in Somerset. The walk starts from the village of Whitelackington, just to the east of the hall. From here you can follow a shared cycling and walking trail west to reach the house. The house dates from the 16th century and is notable as the former home of Prime Minister Lord North. At the house you could enjoy a fine Sunday roast or a lovely afternoon tea before enjoying a stroll around the parkland and gardens. There's also some nice trails through the woodland where you can see bluebells in the spring months.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The woodland and parkland on the estate are a nice place to bring your dog for a walk.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your walking in the area you could visit the Iron Age Hillfort at Castle Neroche or enjoy a waterside walk around Chard Reservoir. For more walking ideas in the area see the Blackdown Hills Walks page.

display_address: Dillington, Whitelackington, Somerset, England, TA19 9EH, United Kingdom
